trumpet, unconsciously and quite forgetting her condition, prepared for the fa- miliar gallop of coquetry, without any ulterior motive or any struggle, but with naive and lighthearted gaiety. 
Although in female society Anatole usually assumed the role of a man tired of being run after by women, his vanity was flattered by the spectacle of his power over these three women. Besides that, he was beginning to feel for the pretty and provocative Mademoiselle Bouri- enne that passionate animal feel
